question: A.1 [1.0 point] Attached is the applicable portion from the chart of the nuclides, what will U-234 decay into?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Chart of the Nuclides (α decay: U-234  Th-230)
Incorrect. Reference: Chart of the Nuclides (α decay: U-234  Th-230)
Correct. Reference: Chart of the Nuclides (α decay: U-234  Th-230)
Incorrect. Reference: Chart of the Nuclides (α decay: U-234  Th-230)

question: A.2 [1.0 point] In a subcritical reactor with Keff of 0.931, a reactivity worth of 0.017 Δk is inserted into the reactor core.  Which ONE of the following is the NEW Keff?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. ∆ρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2).  0.017 = (x-0.931)/(x*0.931); 0.017*0.931*x =x-0.931 0.01583x=x-0.931; 0.98417x =0.931; x=0.931/0.98417; x=0.946

Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. ∆ρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2).  0.017 = (x-0.931)/(x*0.931); 0.017*0.931*x =x-0.931 0.01583x=x-0.931; 0.98417x =0.931; x=0.931/0.98417; x=0.946

Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. ∆ρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2).  0.017 = (x-0.931)/(x*0.931); 0.017*0.931*x =x-0.931 0.01583x=x-0.931; 0.98417x =0.931; x=0.931/0.98417; x=0.946

Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. ∆ρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2).  0.017 = (x-0.931)/(x*0.931); 0.017*0.931*x =x-0.931 0.01583x=x-0.931; 0.98417x =0.931; x=0.931/0.98417; x=0.946

question: A.3 [1.0 point] The reactor is critical.  The reactor operator accidentally inserts a fuel element in the core and Keff changes to 1.010.   What is the period of the reactor? Given a prompt neutron lifetime (ℓ*) of 1 x 10 -4 seconds.

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Using equations provided in the equation sheet: ρ = (1.01-1)/1.01 ρ = 0.01 For prompt, T = ℓ*/ρ = 0.0001/0.01 = 0.01 sec
Correct. Reference: Using equations provided in the equation sheet: ρ = (1.01-1)/1.01 ρ = 0.01 For prompt, T = ℓ*/ρ = 0.0001/0.01 = 0.01 sec
Incorrect. Reference: Using equations provided in the equation sheet: ρ = (1.01-1)/1.01 ρ = 0.01 For prompt, T = ℓ*/ρ = 0.0001/0.01 = 0.01 sec
Incorrect. Reference: Using equations provided in the equation sheet: ρ = (1.01-1)/1.01 ρ = 0.01 For prompt, T = ℓ*/ρ = 0.0001/0.01 = 0.01 sec

A.4 [1.0 point] The following data was obtained during a reactor fuel load.

No. of Elements
Detector A (count/min)
     
0
300
10
400
20
600
30
1000
50
3000
Which ONE of the following is the closest number of fuel elements required to make the reactor critical?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 5.5, page 5-18-5-25.
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 5.5, page 5-18-5-25.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 5.5, page 5-18-5-25.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 5.5, page 5-18-5-25.

question: A.5 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is the most correct reason for having an installed neutron source within the core? An installed neutron source is very important during startup because without of a neutron source...

answers.answer: a. the reactor could result in a sudden increase in power if the control rods were pulled out far enough
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: NRC Standard

answers.answer: b. the compensating voltage on the source range detector doesn’t work
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: NRC Standard

answers.answer: c. the startup channel would NEVER indicate neutron population
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: NRC Standard

answers.answer: d. the chain reaction in the reactor core would NOT start
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: NRC Standard

question: A.6 [1.0 point] Two critical reactors at low power are identical, except that Reactor 1 has a beta fraction of 0.0065 and Reactor 2 has a beta fraction of 0.0072.  Which ONE of the following best describes the response if an equal amount of positive reactivity is inserted into both reactors?

answers.answer: a. Period of the Reactor 1 will be longer than the period of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Equation Sheet. τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]. Since the period of the reactor 1 is shorter than the reactor 2, the trace (power vs. time) of the Reactor 1 will be higher than the trace of the Reactor 2

answers.answer: b. The final power in the Reactor 1 will be lower than the final power in the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Equation Sheet. τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]. Since the period of the reactor 1 is shorter than the reactor 2, the trace (power vs. time) of the Reactor 1 will be higher than the trace of the Reactor 2

answers.answer: c. The trace (power vs. time) of the Reactor 1 will be higher than the trace of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Equation Sheet. τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]. Since the period of the reactor 1 is shorter than the reactor 2, the trace (power vs. time) of the Reactor 1 will be higher than the trace of the Reactor 2

answers.answer: d. The trace (power vs. time) of the Reactor 1 will be identical to the trace of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Equation Sheet. τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]. Since the period of the reactor 1 is shorter than the reactor 2, the trace (power vs. time) of the Reactor 1 will be higher than the trace of the Reactor 2

question: A.7 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following best describes the effects of moderator temperature increase on neutron multiplication?

answers.answer: a. Resonance escape probability ↑; Thermal non-leakage↓; Rod worth ↑
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2 K_eff - 1 = ρ

answers.answer: b. Resonance escape probability ↓; Thermal non-leakage↓; Rod worth ↑
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2 K_eff - 1 = ρ

answers.answer: c. Resonance escape probability ↑; Thermal non-leakage↑; Rod worth ↓
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2 K_eff - 1 = ρ

answers.answer: d. Resonance escape probability ↓; Thermal non-leakage↓; Rod worth ↓
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2 K_eff - 1 = ρ

question: A.8 [1.0 point] In a just critical reactor, the reactor operator immediately inserts a rabbit of 0.005 Δk reactivity worth into the core.  This insertion will cause: Given:T: reactor period, ℓ*: Prompt neutron lifetime; ρ: reactivity insertion; β: beta fraction

answers.answer: a. A sudden drop in delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: b. A number of prompt neutrons equals to a number of delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: c. The resultant period to be a function of the prompt neutron lifetime (T=ℓ*/ρ)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: d. A sudden change of power that equals to the initial power multiplied by β(1- ρ)/ (β -ρ)
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

question: A.9 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is the MAIN reason for operating with thermal neutrons instead of fast neutrons?

answers.answer: a. Decrease β-eff, so it is easy to control the reactor.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Figure 2.6, page 2-39

answers.answer: b. Moderator temperature coefficient becomes positive as neutron energy increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Figure 2.6, page 2-39

answers.answer: c. Neutron absorption in non fuel material increases exponentially as neutron energy increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Figure 2.6, page 2-39

answers.answer: d. The fission cross section of the fuel is much higher for thermal energy neutrons than fast neutrons.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Figure 2.6, page 2-39

question: A.10 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is a correct statement of why delayed neutrons enhance the ability to control reactor power?

answers.answer: a. Delayed neutrons are born at higher energy levels than prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 3.3.7, page 3-37

answers.answer: b. Prompt neutrons can cause fissions in both U-235 and U-238; whereas delayed neutrons can only cause fissions in U-235
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 3.3.7, page 3-37

answers.answer: c. The average number of delayed neutrons produced per fission is higher than the average number of prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 3.3.7, page 3-37

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons increase the average neutron lifetime that allows a reactor to be controlled
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 3.3.7, page 3-37

question: A.11 [1.0 point] During a reactor startup, the reactor operator observes the position of the current control rods is LOWER than the last startup.  Which ONE of the following reasons could be the cause?

answers.answer: a. Higher moderator temperature (assume negative temperature coefficient)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC question.

answers.answer: b. Insertion of a negative reactivity worth experiment
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC question.
Correct. Reference: Standard NRC question.
Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC question.

question: A.12 [1.0 point] A reactor with Keff = 0.8 contributes 1000 neutrons in the first generation.  Changing from the first generation to the THIRD generation, how many TOTAL neutrons are there after the third generation?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.3, p. 5.6 3-nd generation=n + K*n + K2 *n=1000+800+640= 2440neutrons
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.3, p. 5.6 3-nd generation=n + K*n + K2 *n=1000+800+640= 2440neutrons
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.3, p. 5.6 3-nd generation=n + K*n + K2 *n=1000+800+640= 2440neutrons
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.3, p. 5.6 3-nd generation=n + K*n + K2 *n=1000+800+640= 2440neutrons

question: A.13 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following will be the resulting stable reactor period when a 0.00245 ∆k reactivity insertion is made into an exactly critical reactor core?  Neglect any effects from prompt.  Given β =0.0070 and λ=0.1

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: T = (β-ρ)/λρ T = (0.0070 - 0.00245)/0.1 x 0.00245 = 18.57 seconds
Incorrect. Reference: T = (β-ρ)/λρ T = (0.0070 - 0.00245)/0.1 x 0.00245 = 18.57 seconds
Correct. Reference: T = (β-ρ)/λρ T = (0.0070 - 0.00245)/0.1 x 0.00245 = 18.57 seconds
Incorrect. Reference: T = (β-ρ)/λρ T = (0.0070 - 0.00245)/0.1 x 0.00245 = 18.57 seconds

question: A.14 [1.0 point] An example of a FISSIONABLE NUCLEI is:

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, 1988 Section 3.2 page 3-2
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, 1988 Section 3.2 page 3-2

question: A.15 [1.0 point] About few minutes following a reactor scram, the reactor period has stabilized and the power level is decreasing at a CONSTANT rate.  Given that reactor power at time t0 is 100 kW power, what will it be five minutes later?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-T/J = 100 kW H e(300sec/-80sec) = 100 kW H e-3.75 = 0.0235 H 100 kW = 2.35 KW
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-T/J = 100 kW H e(300sec/-80sec) = 100 kW H e-3.75 = 0.0235 H 100 kW = 2.35 KW
Correct. Reference: P = P0 e-T/J = 100 kW H e(300sec/-80sec) = 100 kW H e-3.75 = 0.0235 H 100 kW = 2.35 KW
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-T/J = 100 kW H e(300sec/-80sec) = 100 kW H e-3.75 = 0.0235 H 100 kW = 2.35 KW

question: A.16 [1.0 point] The reactor is STARTED UP following a SHUTDOWN.  Which ONE of the following statements is true about xenon?

answers.answer: a. The concentration of Xe135 will increase due to decay of Cs135
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 8.4.2

answers.answer: b. The concentration of Xe135 will increase due to increase nuclear flux
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 8.4.2

answers.answer: c. The concentration of Xe135 will decrease due to the burnout of the Xe135 inventory
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 8.4.2

answers.answer: d. The concentration of Xe135 will remain constant due to equilibrium of xenon burnout and xenon production
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 8.4.2

question: A.17 [1.0 point] Which ONE statement below describes a NEGATIVE moderator temperature coefficient?

answers.answer: a. When moderator temperature increases, negative reactivity is added
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 6.4

answers.answer: b. When moderator temperature decreases, negative reactivity is added
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 6.4

answers.answer: c. When moderator temperature increases, positive reactivity is added
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 6.4

answers.answer: d. When moderator temperature increases, no change in reactivity
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 6.4

question: A.18 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following factors in the “six factor” formula is the MOST affected by the CONTROL BLADES?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.2.2, page 3-18.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.2.2, page 3-18.
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.2.2, page 3-18.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.2.2, page 3-18.

question: A.19 [1.0 point] Given a source strength of 300 neutrons per second (N/sec) and a multiplication factor of 0.7, which ONE of the following is the expected stable neutron count rate?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: CR = S/(1-K)  →  CR = 300/(1 - .7) = 1000
Correct. Reference: CR = S/(1-K)  →  CR = 300/(1 - .7) = 1000
Incorrect. Reference: CR = S/(1-K)  →  CR = 300/(1 - .7) = 1000
Incorrect. Reference: CR = S/(1-K)  →  CR = 300/(1 - .7) = 1000

question: A.20 [1.0 point] The injection of a sample results in a 50 millisecond period.  If the scram setpoint is 5 MEGAWATTS and the scram delay time is 0.1 seconds, which ONE of the following is the peak power of the reactor at shutdown?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, P = P0 et/τ, P = 5 megawatts × e0.1/0.05 = 5 × e2 = 37 megawatts
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, P = P0 et/τ, P = 5 megawatts × e0.1/0.05 = 5 × e2 = 37 megawatts
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, P = P0 et/τ, P = 5 megawatts × e0.1/0.05 = 5 × e2 = 37 megawatts
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, P = P0 et/τ, P = 5 megawatts × e0.1/0.05 = 5 × e2 = 37 megawatts
